src_text.0: Μῆτερ ἐμή, τίφθ’ ὧδε φίλον κατὰ θυμὸν ἰάπτεις ἐκπάγλως ἀχέουσα, τὸ πρὶν δέ τοι οὐκέτ’ ἔρευθος σῴζετ’ ἐπὶ ῥεθέεσσι;
src_text.2: ἦρ’ ὅτι ἄλγεα πάσχει ἀπείριτα φαίδιμος υἱὸς ἀνδρὸς ὕπ’ οὐτιδανοῖο, λέων ὡσείθ’ ὑπὸ νεβροῦ;
src_text.3: ὤμοι ἐγώ, τί νυ δή με θεοὶ τόσον ἠτίμησαν ἀθάνατοι;
src_text.4: τί νύ μ’ ὧδε κακῇ γονέες τέκον αἴσῃ;
src_text.5: δύσμορος, ἥτ’ ἐπεὶ ἀνδρὸς ἀμύμονος ἐς λέχος ἦλθον, τὸν μὲν ἐγὼ τίεσκον ἴσον φαέεσσιν ἐμοῖσιν ἠδ’ ἔτι νῦν σέβομαί τε καὶ αἰδέομαι κατὰ θυμόν· τοῦ δ’ οὔτις γένετ’ ἄλλος ἀποτμότερος ζωόντων, οὐδὲ τόσων σφετέρῃσιν ἐγεύσατο φροντίσι κηδέων.
src_text.6: σχέτλιος, ὃς τόξοισιν, ἅ οἱ πόρεν αὐτὸς Ἀπόλλων ἠέ τινος Κηρῶν ἢ Ἐρινύος αἰνὰ βέλεμνα, παῖδας ἑοὺς κατέπεφνε καὶ ἐκ φίλον εἵλετο θυμὸν μαινόμενος κατὰ οἶκον, ὃ δ’ ἔμπλεος ἔσκε φόνοιο.
src_text.7: τοὺς μὲν ἐγὼ δύστηνος ἐμοῖς ἴδον ὀφθαλμοῖσι βαλλομένους ὑπὸ πατρί, τὸ δ’ οὐδ’ ὄναρ ἤλυθεν ἄλλῳ.
src_text.8: οὐδέ σφιν δυνάμην ἀδινὸν καλέουσιν ἀρῆξαι μητέρ’ ἑήν, ἐπεὶ ἐγγὺς ἀνίκητον κακὸν ἦεν.
src_text.9: ὡς δ’ ὄρνις δύρηται ἐπὶ σφετέροισι νεοσσοῖς ὀλλυμένοις, οὕστ’ αἰνὸς ὄφις ἔτι νηπιάχοντας θάμνοις ἐν πυκινοῖσι κατεσθίει· ἣ δὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς πωτᾶται κλάζουσα μάλα λιγὺ πότνια μήτηρ, οὐδ’ ἄρ’ ἔχει τέκνοισιν ἐπαρκέσαι· ἦ γάρ οἱ αὐτῇ ἆσσον ἴμεν μέγα τάρβος ἀμειλίκτοιο πελώρου· ὣς ἐγὼ αἰνοτόκεια φίλον γόνον αἰάζουσα μαινομένοισι πόδεσσι δόμον κάτα πολλὸν ἐφοίτων.
src_text.10: ὥς γ’ ὄφελον μετὰ παισὶν ἅμα θνῄσκουσα καὶ αὐτὴ κεῖσθαι φαρμακόεντα δι’ ἥπατος ἰὸν ἔχουσα, Ἄρτεμι θηλυτέρῃσι μέγα κρείουσα γυναιξί.
src_text.11: τῷ χ’ ἡμέας κλαύσαντε φίλῃσ’ ἐνὶ χερσὶ τοκῆες πολλοῖς σὺν κτερέεσσι πυρῆς ἐπέβησαν ὁμοίης, καί κεν ἕνα χρύσειον ἐς ὀστέα κρωσσὸν ἁπάντων λέξαντες κατέθαψαν, ὅθι πρῶτον γενόμεσθα.
src_text.12: νῦν δ’ οἳ μὲν Θήβην ἱπποτρόφον ἐνναίουσιν Ἀονίου πεδίοιο βαθεῖαν βῶλον ἀροῦντες· αὐτὰρ ἐγὼ Τίρυνθα κάτα κραναὴν πόλιν Ἥρης πολλοῖσιν δύστηνος ἰάπτομαι ἄλγεσιν ἦτορ αἰὲν ὁμῶς· δακρύων δὲ παρεστί μοι οὐδ’ ἴ ἐρωή.
src_text.13: ἀλλὰ πόσιν μὲν ὁρῶ παῦρον χρόνον ὀφθαλμοῖσιν οἴκῳ ἐν ἡμετέρῳ· πολέων γάρ οἱ ἔργον ἑτοῖμον μόχθων, τοὺς ἐπὶ γαῖαν ἀλώμενος ἠδὲ θάλασσαν μοχθίζει πέτρης ὅγ’ ἔχων νόον ἠὲ σιδήρου καρτερὸν ἐν στήθεσσι· σὺ δ’ ἠύτε λείβεαι ὕδωρ, νύκτας τε κλαίουσα καὶ ἐκ Διὸς ἤμαθ’ ὁπόσσα.
src_text.14: ἄλλος μὰν οὐκ ἄν τις ἐϋφρήναι με παραστὰς κηδεμόνων· οὐ γάρ σφε δόμων κατὰ τεῖχος ἐέργει· καὶ λίην πάντες γε πέρην πιτυώδεος Ἰσθμοῦ ναίουσ’ , οὐδέ μοί ἐστι πρὸς ὅντινά κε βλέψασα οἷα γυνὴ πανάποτμος ἀναψύξαιμι φίλον κῆρ, νόσφι γε δὴ Πύρρης συνομαίμονος· ἣ δὲ καὶ αὐτὴ ἀμφὶ πόσει σφετέρῳ πλέον ἄχνυται Ἰφικλῆι, σῷ υἱεῖ· πάντων γὰρ ὀϊζυρώτατα τέκνα γείνασθαί σε θεῷ τε καὶ ἀνέρι θνητῷ ἔολπα.
src_text.15: ὣς ἄρ’ ἔφη· τὰ δέ οἱ θαλερώτερα δάκρυα μήλων κόλπον ἐς ἱμερόεντα κατὰ βλεφάρων ἐχέοντο, μνησαμένῃ τέκνων τε καὶ ὧν μετέπειτα τοκήων.
src_text.16: ὣς δ’ αὔτως δακρύοισι παρήϊα λεύκ’ ἐδίαινεν Ἀλκμήνη· βαρὺ δ’ ἥγε καὶ ἐκ θυμοῦ στενάχουσα μύθοισιν πυκινοῖσι φίλην νυὸν ὧδε μετηύδα· δαιμονίη παίδων, τί νύ τοι φρεσὶν ἔμπεσε τοῦτο πευκαλίμαις;
src_text.17: πῶς ἄμμ’ ἐθέλεις ὀροθυνέμεν ἄμφω κήδἐ ἄλαστα λέγουσα;
src_text.18: τὰ δ’ οὐ νῦν πρῶτα κέκλαυται.
src_text.19: ἢ οὐκ ἅλις, οἷς ἐχόμεσθα τὸ δεύτατον αἰὲν ἐπ’ ἦμαρ γινομένοις;
src_text.20: μάλα μέν γε φιλοθρηνής κέ τις εἴη, ὅστις ἀριθμήσειεν ἐφ’ ἡμετέροις ἀχέεσσι.
src_text.21: θάρσει· οὐ τοιῆσδ’ ἐκυρήσαμεν ἐκ θεοῦ αἴσης.
src_text.22: καὶ δ’ αὐτὴν ὁρόω σε φίλον τέκος ἀτρύτοισιν ἄλγεσι μοχθίζουσαν.
src_text.23: ἐπιγνώμων δέ τοί εἰμι ἀσχαλάαν, ὅτε δή γε καὶ εὐφροσύνης κόρος ἐστί· καί σε μάλ’ ἐκπάγλως ὀλοφύρομαι ἠδ’ ἐλεαίρω, οὕνεκεν ἡμετέροιο λυγροῦ μετὰ δαίμονος ἔσχες, ὅσθ’ ἡμῖν ἐφύπερθε κάρης βαρὺς αἰωρεῖται.
src_text.24: ἴστω γὰρ Κούρη τε καὶ εὐέανος Δημήτηρ, ἅς κε μέγα βλαφθείς τις ἑκὼν ἐπίορκον ὀμόσσαι δυσμενέων, μηθέν σε χερειότερον φρεσὶν ᾗσι στέργειν ἢ εἴπερ μοι ὑπὲκ νηδυιόφιν ἦλθες καί μοι τηλυγέτη ἐνὶ δώμασι παρθένος ἦσθα.
src_text.25: οὐδ’ αὐτήν γέ νυ πάμπαν ἔολπά σε τοῦτό γε λήθειν.
src_text.26: τῷ μή μ’ ἐξείπῃς ποτ̓, ἐμὸν θάλος, ὥς σευ ἀκηδέω, μηδ’ εἴ κ’ ἠϋκόμου Νιόβης πυκινώτερα κλαίω.
src_text.27: οὐδ’ ὣς γὰρ νεμεσητὸν ὑπὲρ τέκνου γοάασθαι μητέρι δυσπαθέοντος· ἐπεὶ δέκα μῆνας ἔκαμνον πρὶν καί πέρ τ’ ἰδέειν μιν, ἐμῷ ὑπὸ ἥπατ’ ἔχουσα, καί με πυλάρταο σχεδὸν ἤγαγεν Αἰδωνῆος· ὧδέ ἑ δυστοκέουσα κακὰς ὠδῖνας ἀνέτλην.
src_text.28: νῦν δέ μοι οἴχεται οἶος ἐπ’ ἀλλοτρίης νέον ἆθλον ἐκτελέων· οὐδ’ οἶδα δυσάμμορος, εἴτε μιν αὖτις ἐνθάδε νοστήσανθ’ ὑποδέξομαι, εἴτε καὶ οὐκί.
src_text.29: πρὸς δ’ ἔτι μ’ ἐπτοίησε διὰ γλυκὺν αἰνὸς ὄνειρος ὕπνον· δειμαίνω δὲ παλιγκοτον ὄψιν ἰδοῦσα ἐκπάγλως, μή μοί τι τέκνοις ἀποθύμιον ἔρδοι.
src_text.30: εἴσατο γάρ μοι ἔχων μακέλην εὐεργέα χερσὶ παῖς ἐμὸς ἀμφοτέρῃσι, βίη Ἡρακληείη· τῇ μεγάλην ἐλάχαινε δεδεγμένος ὡς ἐπὶ μισθῷ τάφρον τηλεθάοντος ἐπ’ ἐσχατιῇ τινος ἀγροῦ, γυμνὸς ἄτερ χλαίνης τε καὶ εὐμίτροιο χιτῶνος.
src_text.31: αὐτὰρ ἐπειδὴ παντὸς ἀφίκετο πρὸς τέλος ἔργου καρτερὸν οἰνοφόροιο πονεύμενος ἕρκος ἀλωῆς, ἤτοι ὃ λίστρον ἔμελλεν ἐπὶ προύχοντος ἐρείσας ἀνδήρου καταδῦναι, ἃ καὶ πάρος εἵματα ἕστο· ἐξαπίνης δ’ ἀνελάμψεν ὑπὲρ καπέτοιο βαθείης πῦρ ἄμοτον, περὶ δ’ αὐτὸν ἀθέσφατος εἰλεῖτο φλόξ.
src_text.32: αὐτὰρ ὅγ’ αἰὲν ὄπισθε θοοῖς ἀνεχάζετο ποσσίν, ἐκφυγέειν μεμαὼς ὀλοὸν μένος Ἡφαίστοιο· αἰεὶ δὲ προπάροιθεν ἑοῦ χροὸς ἠΰτε γέρρον νώμασκεν μακέλην· περὶ δ’ ὄμμασιν ἔνθα καὶ ἔνθα πάπταινεν, μὴ δή μιν ἐπιφλέξει δήιον πῦρ.
src_text.33: τῷ μὲν ἀοσσῆσαι λελιημένος, ὥς μοι ἔϊκτο, Ἰφικλέης μεγάθυμος ἐπ’ οὔδεϊ κάππεσ’ ὀλισθὼν πρὶν ἐλθεῖν, οὐδ’ ὀρθὸς ἀναστῆναι δύνατ’ αὖτις, ἀλλ’ ἀστεμφὲς ἔκειτο, γέρων ὡσείτ’ ἀμενηνός, ὅντε καὶ οὐκ ἐθέλοντα βιήσατο γῆρας ἀτερπὲς καππεσέειν· κεῖται δ’ ὅγ’ ἐπὶ χθονὸς ἔμπεδον αὔτως, εἰσόκε τις χειρός μιν ἀνειρύσσῃ παριόντων αἰδεσθεὶς ὄπιδα προτέρην πολιοῖο γενείου.
src_text.34: ὣς ἐν γῇ λελίαστο σακεσπάλος Ἰφικλείης· αὐτὰρ ἐγὼ κλαίεσκον ἀμηχανέοντας ὁρῶσα παῖδας ἐμούς, μέχρι δή μοι ἀπέσσυτο νήδυμος ὕπνος ὀφθαλμῶν, ἠὼς δὲ παραυτίκα φαινόλις ἦλθε.
src_text.35: τοῖα, φίλη, μοι ὄνειρα διὰ φρένας ἐπτοίησαν παννυχίῃ· τὰ δὲ πάντα πρὸς Εὐρυσθῆα τρέποιτο οἴκου ἄφ’ ἡμετέροιο, γένοιτο δὲ μάντις ἐκείνῳ θυμὸς ἐμός, μηδ’ ἄλλο παρὲκ τελέσειέ τι δαίμων.

tgt_text.0: FOR the biography of the foremost of Bucolic minstrels, the pastoral poet Theocritus, unfortunately few materials exist.
tgt_text.1: Indeed the little which is known is inferred either from the actual poems of Theocritus himself, or from such as have been published under his name.
tgt_text.2: Of the latter class is the 22nd epigram, from which we gather his parentage and birth-place, and which is generally held to have been the work of Ar­ temidorus the grammarian.
tgt_text.3: Evidently written with a view to distinguishing between our poet and his Chian namesake, an orator and sophist, it fixes for his native place Syracuse, and for his parents Praxagoras and Philinna.
tgt_text.4: With this account Suidas substantially agrees, though he adds that some make Theocritus the son of Simichus, or Simichidas, and holds that, being originally a native of Cos, he had become a metæch or foreign settler at Syracuse.
tgt_text.5: Now if we compare this notion with the Scholia on the 7th Idyll, vs. 21, (where it is suggested by some that the name is an assumed one, derived from σίμος, flat-nosed,) as well as with the Θεοκϱίτου γένος, it seems that a confusion has arisen with regard to the identity of Theocritus with Simichidas, into whose mouth the 7th Idyll is put.
tgt_text.6: It does not seem to have occurred to those who make Simi­ chus the father of the Syracusan poet, that bards are wont to shadow forth their own words, thoughts, and acts, under ficti­ tious names and unreal characters, and that Theocritus might really have described what happened to himself in the "Thaly­ sia," and yet not have used the name of Simichidas, otherwise than Virgil uses that of Tityrus.
tgt_text.7: —Nor is there any reason to suppose that the claims of Cos to the honour of his birth and early training rest on stronger grounds than that he studied under Philetus of Cos, whom he mentions in Idyll vii.
tgt_text.8: 40, whe­ ther at Cos itself or in Alexandria is not clear.
tgt_text.9: Of Philetus,. and Asclepiades, of whom he speaks as τὸν ἐσθλὸν Σικελίδαν το̃ν ἐκ Σάμω, (Idyll vii. 40,) it is known that they were dis­ tinguished poets of the Alexandrian school, whom Theocritus professedly admired, and of the former of whom he was pro­ bably a pupil.
tgt_text.10: There is internal evidence in the Idylls of the poet, that I resided for some space at Alexandria, and afterwards at Syracuse, whilst the 7th Idyll shows such a knowledge of the localities of Cos, as could hardly, one should think, have been obtained without a personal acquaintance with the island.
tgt_text.11: Here may have arisen his intimacy with Ni­ cias of Miletus, the physician to whom he dedicated the 11th and 13th Idylls, and to whose wife, Theugenis, he wrote a pleasing ditty, (28th,) with a silver distaff.
tgt_text.12: -But this is mere conjecture, arising probably out of the nearness of Cos to Miletus.
tgt_text.13: To Alexandria Theocritus was no doubt at­ tracted by the fame of its library, founded by Ptolemy Soter, and raised to its highest point of eminence by his son Philadelphus, under whose care it became the resort of tht, most distinguished literati of the day, Zenodotus, Callimachus, Hegesias, Euclid, Aratus.
tgt_text.14: To the last of these, the astro­ nomer and poet, who was the author of the Phænomena, he addressed his 6th Idyll, and his name occurs again in the Idyll following.
tgt_text.15: Association with such a man would not be without its advantages, and we here and there discover traces of his having imbibed from his friend some acquaintance with astronomical matters.
tgt_text.16: But it was probably at Alex­ andria, too, that he found access to the pages of the Septua­ gint, itself a lasting monument of the Egyptian monarch's zeal in the collection of literary treasures.
tgt_text.17: No one can read the 16th, 18th, 20th, and 23rd Idylls without being struck by the similarity of thought and expression of passages in each, to portions of the Psalms of David, the Book of Job, the Song of Solomon, and the Prophecies of Isaiah.
tgt_text.18: The parallels have been pointed out in the notes to the present translation:
tgt_text.19: but the strength of internal evidence to the supposition that Theo­ critus availed himself of the access, which he might undoubt­ edly have had, to the Septuagint, receives additional force in the comparison of the whole scene of altercation between Pollux and Amycus with the historical record of the encounter be­ tween David and Goliath in the First Book of Samuel.
tgt_text.20: It can hardly be doubted that Theocritus composed the 14th, 15th, and 17th Idylls at Alexandria :
tgt_text.21: he could not have enjoyed even the passing favour and brief notice of Ptolemy Phila­ delphus, without becoming interested in the law and records of that strange race, the Jews of many wanderings ;
tgt_text.22: one hun­ dred and twenty thousand of whom had been liberated by that monarch from the slavery in which Ptolemy Soter had bound them.
tgt_text.24: 2) writes at length respecting the interest shown by Ptolemy Philadelphus in obtaining for his vast library an accurate translation of the Books of the Old Testament.
tgt_text.25: We find from him how the monarch strove to purchase the good will of the nation by sending splendid gifts to the God of Israel:
tgt_text.26: how he valued the translators and their translations :
tgt_text.27: and how he conversed with his librarian, Demetrius Phalereus, on the deep meaning and superior wisdom of the Jewish law.
tgt_text.28: And we know enough of the tide of fashion, especially if it is royal taste that lifts the floodgate, which carries onward successful literature of any class, to feel sure that a scholar could hardly have tarried even for a brief space at Alexandria without inspect­ ing that volume, which even to heathens was a work of wonder, fostered by reflecting credit upon one of the fore­ most of the then rulers of the world.
tgt_text.29: A poet likewise, im­ bued, as was Theocritus, with a sense of the charm of natural simplicity, and having withal, as some of his poems show, no mean appreciation of the glorious epic, could never have been content with a transient glance at a collection of Such infinite graces, simplicity, grandeur, natural colouring, and noble imagery, as the translation of the Seventy elders, inferior though it be in diction to the original.
tgt_text.31: like others, he dipped often into that well of wisdom, albeit he knew not the spell which renders it sweeter to the taste than all other waters.
tgt_text.32: Hovering around those sacred pages, he caught the scent of flowers of poesy, which he has transferred into his Idylls, and we have the gratification of an involuntary testi­ nony from a heathen poet to the charms of composition and material, with which the sacred volume is so richly fraught.
tgt_text.33: Our taste will be wilfully dull, if it acknowledge not the extreme probability that the Syracusan saw the Septuagint, and there need be no stumbling-block in the argument that he no where mentions the Jews.
tgt_text.34: He dived for pearls of poesy, leaving unexplored the buried treasures of history and reli­ gion.
tgt_text.35: Without satisfactory data for any certain conclusion, we can at least give the benefit of probabilities in favour of our poet's acquaintance with the Septuagint.
tgt_text.36: From this we pass on to other matter.
tgt_text.37: Theocritus, while at Alexandria, was allowed, we presume, to dedicate his 17th Idyll to Ptolemy Philadelphus ;
tgt_text.38: and we have reason to suppose that the 14th and 15th were com­ posed there also.
tgt_text.39: But it is clear that he did not find the monarch and his capital such kindly fosterers of his Muse as he might have expected:
tgt_text.40: for very soon we find him hymning at Syracuse the praises (considerably qualified by doubts of his open-handedness) of King Hiero the Second.
tgt_text.41: That monarch had ascended the throne B. C. 270 :
tgt_text.42: and the Idyll to which reference has been made, appears to have been written during the 1st Punic War, if we may judge from the allusion which he makes to the failing Carthagi­ nians, and Hiero's alliance with their implacable foe.
tgt_text.43: This would fix the date of the Idyll as 263 B. c.;
tgt_text.44: when a treaty between Hiero and the Romans was concluded.
tgt_text.45: But the rays of courtly favour must have .
tgt_text.46: been here also any thing but warm, the atmosphere chilly, when a poet was to be cher­ ished, or creative genius to be saved from starvation and blight.
tgt_text.47: Hiero's munificence was bestowed rather on kingdoms and potentates, than on minstrels and their songs.
tgt_text.49: Theo­ critus discovered at this point the mistake of trusting in princes for the advancement of poetic excellence:
tgt_text.50: at any rate, the greater portion of his Idylls show him to have sought in the calm tranquillity of country life and pastoral scenery, that independent self-reliance, Which, after all, is the safest nurse of the lovely rhyme.
tgt_text.51: Though when he rises to heroics, as in the encomiums on Ptolemy and Hiero, and in the 22nd, 24th, and 25th Idylls, he fully sustains his reputation, and no where falls into poverty of language, or mediocrity of conception;
tgt_text.52: yet it is on the first eleven Idylls, the 14th, 15th, and 21st, that his title to the fame, which has been universally ac­ corded to him, is most really and justly based.
tgt_text.53: Bion and Moschu3 are pretty conceit-weavers :
tgt_text.54: they sometimes delight US'with passages unrivalled for warmth of colouring and ten­ derness of pathos :
tgt_text.55: -but for simple rural life, accurately and tastefully depicted, for the thorough appreciation of nature, and reliance thereupon for the staple of his song, Theocritus ranks immeasurably above them.
tgt_text.56: He stands alone, with a crowd of imitators at a wide interval of merit.
tgt_text.57: Virgil's Ec­ logues have no inherent stamp of reality about them.
tgt_text.58: We lack the shepherd's account of his own life among his sheep.
tgt_text.59: There is more of polish than of nature.
tgt_text.60: We have the cour­ tier drawing smooth pictures from fancy ;
tgt_text.61: not the passion­ ate lover of the country deriving his materials from the real landscapes on which he is actually looking out.
tgt_text.62: To borrow an apt expression, Virgil's Eclogues are pictures of a polished mind playing at shepherd.
tgt_text.63: And as to our own pastoral writers, Spenser, Pope, Gay, Lyttleton, and Shenstone, none reach to half the height of Bucolic minstrelsy, to which their great model undeniably attained.
tgt_text.64: Spenser's dialect and metre are unfavourable to his subject;
tgt_text.65: and hecan lay no claim to be a true bard of nature ;
tgt_text.66: while it is matter of fact that beneath his rural images there is an under-current of allusion to matters of religion.
tgt_text.67: Who can enjoy with true zest the pastoral, where the shepherd Roffin symbolizes a bishop of Rochester, and the watch-dog Lowder, one of his chaplains ?
tgt_text.69: And as for Pope, whose pretensions rank next, his pastorals deserve credit only because they were written by a boy of sixteen ;
tgt_text.70: it were an insult to compare them with the mature productions of Theocritus.
tgt_text.71: For smoothness of versification, they have indeed won praise from Macaulay and the Earl of Carlisle;
tgt_text.72: but these two most capable judges assign to them no higher meed.
tgt_text.73: Indeed, had Pope's pastorals alone survived their author, we may well question whether his name would have even been remembered.
tgt_text.74: As for the rest, they claim still less right to tread the same ground, to rank in the same order with Theocritus, in that portion of the temple of fame which good taste will always assign to the Pastoral or Bu­ colic poets.
tgt_text.75: Coarse though the Syracusan bard be here and there, he is indeed, as Quinctilian calls him, " admirabilis in suo genere," nor is it any detraction from his well-won laurels that the same critic goes on to say, " sed musa illa rustica et pastoralis non forum mode, verum ipsam etiam urbem reformidat."
tgt_text.77: It must be borne in mind, when we stumble on grave objections against the poems of Theocritus, that his idea of simplicity is not a transcendental, but a natural one.
tgt_text.78: He has no model Arcadia in view :
tgt_text.79: his eye is all the while upon the woods and vales and river pastures of his native Sicily ;
tgt_text.80: taking his shepherds as he found them there, mak­ in,, them speak what they did speak, not what they ought to have spoken.
tgt_text.81: There are blemishes to his Idylls, which cer­ tainly render an expurgated edition of them a desideratum :
tgt_text.82: but these affect more or less all the chief writers of antiquity.
tgt_text.83: The question however which is just now dividing the educa­ tional world of France, seems to us to admit of but one solu­ tion.
tgt_text.84: What is true of most of the Greek and Latin Classics, is of course true of Theocritus, as one of them.

tgt_text.210: Crossing the Ægean, it found one of its most eminent cultivators in Tyr­ tæus, the poet whom tradition has handed down to us as the Athenian present to their hereditary enemies the Spartans, when they had been directed by the Delphic oracle to seek a leader from Athens for the second Messenian war.
tgt_text.211: The story runs, that Athens, never hearty towards Sparta, save in her hatred, sent her the worst selection that, according to ap­ pearances, could be made,-a lame schoolmaster and composer of verses, who dwelt at Aphidnæ, a village of Attica :

tgt_text.231: and when the foe was vanquish-The Poet, proposing to celebrate the end of Daphnis, the hero of Sicilian shepherds, finds an opening of his subject in a dialogue be­ tween a goatherd and a shepherd named Thyrsis.

tgt_text.358: Simaetha, a maid of Syracuse, of middle rank, (70—74,) seeing herself slighted by Delphis, of whom she is enamoured, becomes suspicious and jealous, and strives to regain his love by charms and philters.
tgt_text.359: At night, by the light of the moon, she holds a magic rite, to which chosen attendants are admitted.
tgt_text.360: The object of these is, that the per­ son on whom the charm is designed to work, may suffer the same as the inanimate objects used in the ceremonial.
tgt_text.361: The rite being over, and Thestylis gone, Simætha details the rise and progress of her love, and her suspicions of the faithlessness of Delphis, addressing herself to the Moon, as presiding over the solemnity.
tgt_text.362: Lastly, she threatens heavy doom to the faithless youth, if he return not to his love for her.

tgt_text.554: Two hireling herdsmen chat together without any fixed subject of conversation.
tgt_text.555: The one, Corydon, is tending the herds of Ægon, who has become a wrestler and gone with Milo to the Olympic games.
tgt_text.556: The other, Bat­ tus, is a man of a sarcastic turn, and keeps annoying his fellow with various sharp sayings;
tgt_text.557: above all, predicting death to the ill-tended herds of Ægon.
tgt_text.558: Corydon, being easy and good-tempered, answers him mildly.
tgt_text.559: While they are chatting, the calves bark the straying olive branches, and Battus, driving them off, is pricked by a thorn.
tgt_text.560: While Corydon is tending his wound, they spy the old father of AEgon, and get into a smart talk about his wanton way of living.
tgt_text.561: This Idyll abounds in pictures of pastoral life and manners.
tgt_text.562: Its scene is laid in the country, at the foot of an olive-clad hill.

tgt_text.671: Two hirelings, one of Eumaras, a goatherd of Sybaris, the other of a shep­ herd of Thurium, meeting each other with their flocks, mutually pro­ voke a conflict of words.
tgt_text.672: At last, after many recriminations, the one challenges the other to a contest in singing:
tgt_text.673: and when they have disputed much about the prize for the victor, and the spot for the trial, they fetch one Morson, a woodcutter, for umpire.
tgt_text.674: They engage in an Amæbæan or alternate strain, in which, with no fixt subject, they wander through various topics,, supplied either by the condition of the singers, the nature of the country and spot, the memory of the past, or by their very anger and inclination.
tgt_text.675: At last Morson adjudges the prize to Comatas ;
tgt_text.676: who, on receiving it, brags of it proudly, and promises to offer a victim to the Nymphs.
tgt_text.677: Much of this Idyll, though not to the taste of our more refined age, is yet eminent for its poetic power and lively colouring of rustic manners.
tgt_text.678: Its scene is a glade near Sybaris in Lower Italy.
tgt_text.679: Virgil has gathered from the Idyll many of the verses, as well as the plan, of his third Eclogue.

tgt_text.923: in this Idyll, one Simichidas is represented describing a celebration of the festival in honour of De meter after harvest, in which he himself and some friends had been engaged at the house of Phrasidamus and Antigenes, on the banks of the Hales.
tgt_text.924: The former part of the Idyll is a narration of the journey to the feast;
tgt_text.925: the latter, a description of the feast itself.
tgt_text.926: On their road, Simichidas and his friends fall in with a goatherd, Lycidas, of great poetic talent, whom they invite to while the length of the way by his song.
tgt_text.927: He accordingly sings, his love for the boy Ageanax.
tgt_text.928: After which, Simichidas in turn celebrates the pas­ sion of Aratus for the lad Philinus.
tgt_text.929: The songs being ended, Lycidas presents Simichidas with a crook, and turns off on another route.
tgt_text.930: The rest go forward to their proposed destination, where beside the mur­ inuring fountain, in a most delightful spot, they indulge in wine and good cheer.
tgt_text.931: The scene, according to the Scholiast, is laid in Cos ;
tgt_text.932: though Heinsius maintains that Sicily is represented.
tgt_text.933: Theocritus is known to have stayed some time at Cos to hear Philetas, which makes for the Scholiast's view.
tgt_text.934: It has been supposed that the poet describes himself under the character of Simichidas, and a Cydonian poet of his own day under the name of Lycidas.
tgt_text.935: Virgil has planned his ninth Eclogue somewhat on the model of this Idyll.1 IT was the time when I and Eucritus were sauntering from the city to the Hales, and with us a third, Amyntas.

tgt_text.950: or art for storming the wine-vats of some cit ?
tgt_text.951: since as thou footest it along, every stone rings, as it strikes against 11 thy half-boots.'

tgt_text.953: which in truth vastly delights my mind ;

tgt_text.956: for our friends in sooth are making a feast to Demeter of the beautiful robe, offering the first-fruits of their abundance :
tgt_text.957: since for them, in very bounteous measure, the goddess hath piled the threshing-floor 13 with barley.

tgt_text.971: '‘Ageanax shall have a fair voyage to Mitylene, when the south wind chases the moist waves 19 in the season of the Kids at-their-setting, and when 20 Orion rests his feet on the ocean, if haply he shall have rescued Lycidas scorched by Aphro­ dite :
tgt_text.972: for ardent love of him consumes me.
tgt_text.973: And halcyons shall 21 smooth the waves, and the sea, and the south-west wind, and the south-east, which stirs the remotest seaweeds:
tgt_text.974: hal­ cyons, which have been beloved most of birds, whose prey is on the sea, by the green Nereids.
tgt_text.975: May all things be season­ able to Ageanax, seeking a fair wind for Mitylene:
tgt_text.976: and may he reach the harbour after a favourable voyage.
tgt_text.977: 22 And I, on that day, crowning my head with a chaplet of dill, or of roses, or even of white 23 violets, will drain from the bowl the 24Pte­ leatic wine, as I recline beside the fire :
tgt_text.978: and one shall roast me a bean in the flame, and the bed of leaves shall be covered- thickly elbow-deep with flea-bane, and asphodel and curling parsley.
tgt_text.979: 25 Then freely will I drink, in memory of Ageanax, pressing my lip to the very cup even to the dregs.
tgt_text.980: 26 And there shall pipe for me two shepherds, one an Acharnian, and one from Lycope:
tgt_text.981: and near them Tityrus shall sing, how once the herdsman Daphnis loved the foreign maid, and how he traversed the mountain, and how the oaks bewailed him which grow beside the banks of the river 27 Himeras :
tgt_text.982: when he wasted away, as any snow on lofty Hæmus, or Athos, or Rhodope, or remotest Caucasus :
tgt_text.983: he shall sing too how once a wide chest received the goatherd yet living, 28 through the baneful vio­ lence of his master;
tgt_text.984: and how the flat-nosed bees coming from the meadows to the sweet cedar, were wont to feed him on soft flowers, because the Muses had poured down his throat pleasant nectar.
tgt_text.985: 0 fortunate Comatas, thou in sooth hast experienced these delights, and thou hast been enclosed in a chest, and thou, being fed on the combs of bees, 29hast com­ pleted the spring of the year.
tgt_text.986: 30 Would that in my day thou hadst been numbered among the living, since I would then have tended for thee thy beautiful she-goats, along the mountains, while listening to thy voice :
tgt_text.987: and thou, divine Comatas, shouldst have reclined under the oaks or under the pines, sweetly singing.
tgt_text.989: And Lycidas having sung thus much, made an end :
tgt_text.990: but to him in turn I also spoke as follows:
tgt_text.991: ‘Many other good things, friend Lycidas, have the Nymphs taught me too, as I tend my herd along the mountains:
tgt_text.992: things which 31 haply fame hath carried even to the throne of Jove.
tgt_text.993: But this at any rate is far pre-eminent beyond all, with which I will proceed to favour you.
tgt_text.994: Hearken then, since you are a friend to the Muses.'32'
tgt_text.995: On Simichidas indeed the Loves have sneezed:
tgt_text.996: for of a truth the luckless wight is as much in love with Myrto, as the she-goats love spring.
tgt_text.997: But Aratus, who is in the highest degree beloved by that man, cherishes at heart a yearning for a lad.
tgt_text.998: 33 Aristis, a worthy man, and highly excellent, (whose singing with the accompaniment of the lyre not even Phœbus himself beside his tripods would refuse,) knows that by a lad Aratus,is consumed to the very bone with love.
tgt_text.999: Him I pray thee, 0 Pan, who hast obtained for thy portion the lovely surface of 34 Homole, mayest thou place unbidden in the dear hands of that man, whether it is in sooth the tender Philinus, or some other. !
tgt_text.1000: And -if indeed thou shouldst do thus, 0 dear PaD, then may 35 Arcadian boys in no wise scourge thee with squills on ribs and shoulders, at such times as scanty feasts are provided:
tgt_text.1001: but shouldst thou have decided otherwise, mayest thou be scratched all over thy flesh by the nails, and mayest thou sleep among nettles:
tgt_text.1002: and in mid-winter mayest thou be on the 36mountains of the Edonians, beside the river Hebrus, facing towards and nigh to the north ;
tgt_text.1003: and in summer mayest thou tend herds among the extremest Æthi­ opians, 37 under the rock of the Blemyes, whence the Nile is no longer to be seen.
tgt_text.1004: But do ye, having left the sweet water of 38 Hyetis and Byblis, and dwelling in the lofty 39 seat of golden-haired Dione, 40 0 Loves like unto ruddy apples, strike, I pray you, with your arrows, the lovely Philinus :
tgt_text.1005: strike, for the wretched youth pities not my guest.
tgt_text.1006: And yet he is more over-ripe than a pear, and the women say, Alas, alas, Philinus, thy beauty's bloom wastes away.

tgt_text.1008: and let Molon alone, my best of friends, be harassed in this sharp exercise:
tgt_text.1009: and to us let both quietness be a care, and an old woman be at hand, who, 42 by spitting, may keep afar off what is not good.

tgt_text.1019: while, from afar off, in the thick thorn-bushes the thrush was warbling.

tgt_text.1022: 46 tawny bees were humming round about the foun­ tains :
tgt_text.1023: all things were breathing-the-incense of very plenteous summer, and breathing-the-incense of fruit-time.

tgt_text.1025: and the boughs hung-in-profusion, weighed down to the ground, with damsons.

tgt_text.1027: Ye Castalian Nymphs, inhabiting the height of Parnassus, I wonder whether 49 at all in the rocky cave of Pholus, aged Chiron set up for Hercules a goblet such as this !
tgt_text.1028: I wonder if haply 'twas nectar like this, which induced that shepherd by the Anapus, the strong Polyphemus, who 50 used to hurl crags on the mountain-ranges, to dance about in the sheep­ pens ?
tgt_text.1029: Such nectar I mean, as, 0 Nymphs, ye then broached, beside the altar of Demeter presiding over the threshing-floor:
tgt_text.1030: on the heap of which may I again fasten a great winnowing shovel, and may she smile, holding in both hands 51 wheat sheaves and poppies.
tgt_text.1031: In this Idyll two pastors are represented as contending, Daphnis and Menalcas, both skilled in music and in Amæbæan song.
tgt_text.1032: A challenge is given, and a prize set up, and a goatherd called in as umpire.
tgt_text.1033: They begin the song, so as to answer one another first with four, afterwards with eight verses each.
tgt_text.1034: At last the goatherd adjudges the prize to Daphnis—and the poet represents this victory as laying the foundation of all the future fame of Daphnis, in pastoral poetry.
tgt_text.1035: The scene is laid in Sicily.
tgt_text.1036: Virgil has copied this Idyll much in Eclogues iii.
tgt_text.1038: MENALCAS, 1as they say, whilst tending his sheep along the high mountains, fell in with the graceful Daphnis a-driving his herd.
tgt_text.1040: Now both of them were 3 red-haired, both lads :
tgt_text.1041: each skilled in playing on the pipes, each in singing.
tgt_text.1042: And first then Menalcas, gazing at Daphnis, addressed him.
tgt_text.1044: Daphnis, watcher of the lowing oxen, wilt thou sing with me ?
tgt_text.1045: I maintain that I will beat you at singing, to my heart's content.
tgt_text.1046: And him, I ween, Daphnis answered in speech like the following.
tgt_text.1048: Shepherd of woolly sheep, piper Menalcas, you at all events shall never beat me in singing, no, not if you should die for it.
tgt_text.1050: Are you desirous then to see into it ?
tgt_text.1051: Are you desirous to stake a prize ?
tgt_text.1053: I do desire to see into this.
tgt_text.1054: I am desirous to stake a prize.
tgt_text.1056: Well what shall we stake, that would be of sufficient value for us ?
tgt_text.1059: and do you stake on your part 5 a lamb like its mother.
tgt_text.1061: 6I will never stake a lamb, for both ray father is strict, and my mother, and they count all the sheep at evening.
tgt_text.1063: Well then, what will you stake ?
tgt_text.1064: And what shall be the advantage the winner shall have ?
tgt_text.1066: A shepherd's-pipe, which I made beautiful with nine notes, and having white wax about it, equal below, equal above.
tgt_text.1068: but my father's property I will not stake.
tgt_text.1070: In truth I too, look you, have a pipe with nine notes, haying white wax about it, equal below, equal above.
tgt_text.1072: Even still I have a pain in this finger, since the reed, i'fegs, split and cut me.
tgt_text.1076: How if we should call hither yon goatherd, whose dog 8 with-the-white-spot, is barking near the kids.
tgt_text.1077: And the youths indeed shouted to him, and the goatherd came, having heard them.
tgt_text.1078: And the youths on their part be­ gan to sing, and the goatherd was willing to be umpire.
tgt_text.1079: So then first the 9 piper Menalcas proceeded to sing, having ob­ tained precedence by lot.
tgt_text.1080: And then Daphnis took up the alternate pastoral strain.
tgt_text.1083: Ye dells and rivers, 10a divine progeny, if haply ever the piper Menalcas has sung a pleasant melody, may ye feed my lambkins 11to my heart's content:
tgt_text.1084: and should Daphnis ever chance to have come with his calves, may he find nothing less.
tgt_text.1086: Ye springs, and herbage, a pleasant growth, if so be that Daphnis warbles like the nightingales, fatten ye this herd!
tgt_text.1087: And if Menalcas shall have driven any stock hither, may he, to his satisfaction, pasture all in plenty.
tgt_text.1089: Every where it is spring, and every where are pas­ tures :
tgt_text.1090: and every where udders are full of milk, and the young are suckled, where the fair maiden approaches:
tgt_text.1091: but if she should depart, both the shepherd is withered there, and the herbage too.
tgt_text.1093: Sheep are there, she-goats with twins are there, bees fill their hives there, and the oaks are loftier, wherever the handsome Milo sets foot;
tgt_text.1094: 13 but should he depart, both he who feeds the heifers, and the heifers themselves, are the more dried up.
tgt_text.1095: Men. 0 he-goat, husband of the white she-goats !
tgt_text.1096: 14 where there is endless depth of foliage, 0 ye flat-nosed kids, come hither to the water.
tgt_text.1097: For in that place is he!
tgt_text.1098: Go, stump-horn, and say to Milo, that 15 Proteus, even though a god, used to feed sea-calves.
tgt_text.1100: Not mine be it to possess the land of Pelops, nor mine to own golden talents, or to outstrip the winds:
tgt_text.1101: but I will sing under this rock, holding thee in my arms, 16looking upon my sheep feeding together, and towards the Sicilian sea.
tgt_text.1103: To trees indeed winter is a dreadful evil, and to waters drought, and to birds the snare, and to wild beasts nets:
tgt_text.1104: but to man the yearning for a tender maiden.
tgt_text.1105: 0 Sire, O Jove, not I alone have been in love.
tgt_text.1106: 17 Thou too art a lover of women.
tgt_text.1107: 'These strains indeed then the youths sang alternately:
tgt_text.1108: and Menalcas thus commenced his concluding song.
tgt_text.1110: Spare my kids, spare, wolf, my she-goats with young, and do not hurt me, because, small though I am, I tend many.
tgt_text.1111: 18 0 dog Lampurus, does so deep a sleep hold you ?
tgt_text.1112: You ought not to sleep soundly while tending sheep with a lad.
tgt_text.1113: And, ye sheep, neither do you shrink from filling yourselves with the tender herbage.
tgt_text.1114: Ye shall be nowise tired of it, when this springs up again.
tgt_text.1115: St! feed on, feed on, and, all of you, fill your udders, that the lambs may have a part, and I may lay up the rest in cheese baskets.
tgt_text.1116: Next in turn, Daphnis struck up to sing sweetly.
tgt_text.1117: Daph. 19 Me too, a maiden with meeting eye-brows, having seen yesterday from her cave, as I drove past it my heifers, kept declaring to be beautiful, beautiful.
tgt_text.1118: Nor indeed did I even answer her a rude word, but kept trudging on my way, looking downwards.
tgt_text.1119: 20 Sweet is the voice of the heifer, sweet the breath of the pipe;

tgt_text.1121: and sweet is it 21 in summer-time to sleep in the open air beside running water.
tgt_text.1122: 22 The acorns are an ornament to the oak, apples to the apple-tree, and to the cows the calf, the cows themselves to the herdsman.
tgt_text.1123: Thus sang the youths, but the goatherd addressed them as follows:

tgt_text.1127: Take the pipe, for thou hast won in singing.

tgt_text.1133: The scene is laid in Sicily.
tgt_text.1134: Daphnis and Menaleas are challenged by a companion shepherd to contend with one another in singing.
tgt_text.1135: They sing in alternate strains, and each carries off a prize;
tgt_text.1136: Daphnis a crook, and Menalcas a muscle-shell.
tgt_text.1137: It seems clear that the whole Idyll is put in the mouth of a shepherd, who narrates the alternate strains of Daphnis and Menalcas, just as Melibæus (Virg. Ecl. vii.) those of Corydon and Thyrsis.
tgt_text.1138: Warton observes that Menalcas in his song assumes the character of the Cyclops.
tgt_text.1139: SING a pastoral strain, Daphnis, and do you first begin the song;
tgt_text.1140: begin you the 1 song, first, and let Menalcas follow after, when you have put the calves to the heifers, and the bulls to the barren cows.
tgt_text.1141: And let them feed together, and stray among the foliage, 2not at all forsaking the herd :
tgt_text.1142: but do you sing me a bucolic strain in the first place ;
tgt_text.1143: and in the next, in turn let Menalcas answer.
tgt_text.1145: Sweetly indeed the calf lows, and sweetly too does the heifer;
tgt_text.1146: and sweetly also the pipe sounds, and the herdsman, and sweetly I too.
tgt_text.1147: And by the cool water-side I have a couch of leaves;
tgt_text.1148: and on it have been strown beautiful skins from white heifers, all of which, to my sorrow, as they nibbled the 3arbute-tree, the south-west wind dashed from the mountain peak.
tgt_text.1149: And I care as much for the parching summer 4as lovers care to hear the words of a father or mother.
tgt_text.1153: Ætna is my mother, and I inhabit a fair cave in the hollow rocks:
tgt_text.1154: and I have in sooth whatever things appear in a dream, 5many sheep and many goats ;
tgt_text.1155: of which the skins lie at my head, and beside my feet.
tgt_text.1156: And on a fire of oak­ boughs entrails are boiling, and on the fire are dry beech- fagots when it is winter ;
tgt_text.1157: and in truth not even have I a care for winter, as much as a toothless person has for nuts, when 6fine meal is at hand.
tgt_text.1159: and straightway gave as a pre­ sent, to Daphnis on one hand a crook, which a field of my father's had raised for me, self sprung, and such as not even perhaps a carpenter would have found fault with;
tgt_text.1160: and to the other 7 a beautiful spiral cockle-shell, the flesh of which I my­ self had eaten, after I had 8 lain in wait for it on the Icarian rocks, having divided 9 five shares for five of us;
tgt_text.1161: and he (Men­ alcas) blew upon the shell.

tgt_text.1165: 11Cicala is dear to cicala, and ant to ant, and hawks to hawks:
tgt_text.1166: but to me the Muse and song :
tgt_text.1167: of which, I pray, may all my house be full, for neither 12 sleep, nor spring on a sudden, is more sweet, nor flowers to bees, than are the Muses dear to me :
tgt_text.1168: for whomso­ ever they behold with pleasure, such hath 13 Circe never at all hurt with her draught.
tgt_text.1169: In this Idyll, which is strictly pastoral, Milo and Battus, two reapers, converse over their work.
tgt_text.1170: Now Battus, being enamoured of a female flute-player, Bombyce, the daughter of Polybutas, or as some suppose his handmaiden, works but slackly in consequence.
tgt_text.1171: Whereupon Milo asks him why he reaps so lazily, and Battus confesses to him his love;
tgt_text.1172: and recites a ditty composed for his mistress.
tgt_text.1173: Milo then opposes to this song, another of his own, containing precepts on the art of reaping, having first applauded Battus for the fitness and beauty of his composition.
tgt_text.1174: You labouring ploughman, what has befallen you now, wretched man ?
tgt_text.1175: Neither can you 1draw the swathe straight, as of old you used to draw it;
tgt_text.1176: nor do you reap in a line with your neighbour, but are left behind, as a sheep, whose foot a thorn has wounded, is left by the flock.
tgt_text.1177: A fine sort of reaper you will be, won't you, at evening, and after mid-day, seeing that now, when you begin, 2 you do not make a gap in the swathe ?
tgt_text.1179: Milo, you who reap till late at even, fragment of stubborn rock, did it never befall you to long after one of the absent ?
tgt_text.1182: And what business has a labouring man with longing after those that are without ?
tgt_text.1184: Did it never then chance to you to lie awake through love ?
tgt_text.1186: No, and I trust it never may.
tgt_text.1187: 3 It's bad to give a dog a taste of guts.
tgt_text.1189: Well, but I, Milo, have been in love hard upon eleven days.

tgt_text.1215: for, O goddesses, ye make all things beautiful, whichsoever ye shall have touched.

tgt_text.1248: This Idyll commences with a preface to Nicias, a physician of Miletus, (to whom Theocritus inscribes the 13th Idyll, and of whom he makes favourable mention in Idyll xxviii. 6, and Epigr. vii. 3,) respecting the power of song in relieving the pains of disappointed love.
tgt_text.1249: The Cyclops is represented as using this solace for his hopeless passion for Galatea.
tgt_text.1250: Polyphemus, sitting on a rock overhanging the sea, beguiles his hours with song.
tgt_text.1251: He accuses the fair one of pride, and scorn for his deep devotion to her;
tgt_text.1252: and boasts of the gifts of fortune, which he can show, in lieu of gifts of beauty and personal grace.
tgt_text.1253: At last he seems to recover from his infatuation, perceiving the vanity of his hopes.
tgt_text.1254: Virgil has had this Idyll in his eye, while writing Eclogues ii.
tgt_text.1256: and Bion perhaps gathered from it some ideas for the first part of his 15th Idyll.
tgt_text.1257: Compare Ovid Met. xiii. 755, &c., and Callimach. Epigr. xlix. p. 316 (Ernesti).1 THERE is no other remedy for love, 0 Nicias, either 2 in the way of salve, as it seems to me, or of plaster, except the Muses :
tgt_text.1258: but this is a light and sweet thing amongst men, yet 'tis not easy to find.
tgt_text.1259: But methinks you know it well, as being a physician, and in truth a man especially beloved by the nine Muses.
tgt_text.1260: Thus, for instance, the famous Cyclops our countryman, the ancient Polyphemus, used most easily to pass his time, when he was enamoured of Galatea, just as he was now getting a beard about his mouth and temples.
tgt_text.1261: And he was wont to love,­ not at all with roses, or apples, or locks of hair, but with un­ done fury:
tgt_text.1262: and he held all things secondary to his fury.
tgt_text.1264: Oft­ times his sheep went back by themselves to the fold from the green herbage ;
tgt_text.1266: Galatea, pined away' there, on the sea-weedy shore, from break of day, having beneath his breast a most hateful wound inflicted by mighty Venus, 4since she had fastened an arrow in his heart.
tgt_text.1268: But he found his remedy, and sitting upon a high rock, looking to­ wards the sea, he was wont to sing such strains as this.'0 fair Galatea, why dost thou spurn thy lover?
tgt_text.1269: 6More white than cream-cheese to look upon, more tender than a lamb, more frisky than a calf, more sleek than an unripe grape ?
tgt_text.1270: And you come hither just so, when sweet sleep'pos­ sesses me, but you are straightway gone, when sweet sleep leaves me;

tgt_text.1277: and one eye is upon my brow, and a broad nostril over the lip.

tgt_text.1280: me not, either in summer, or in autumn, or in the depth of winter;

tgt_text.1283: singing thee, 11my dear sweet-apple, and myself at the same time, 12 oftentimes early in the night.

tgt_text.1288: 15 There are laurels and tapering cypresses, there is black ivy, and the vine with its sweet fruit;
tgt_text.1289: there is cool water, which wooded Ætna sends forth for me, a diving drink, out of white snow:
tgt_text.1290: (who would prefer to these delights to dwell in sea or waves ?)

tgt_text.1296: Mayest thou come out, Galatea, and having come forth, forget (as I do now sitting here) to go away home :
tgt_text.1297: 20 and mayest thou wish to feed flocks with me, and to milk along with me, and to press cheese, infusing sharp runnet.
tgt_text.1298: My mother21 alone wrongs me, and I find fault with her:
tgt_text.1299: not a kind word ever at all has she spoken to you on my behalf, and this too, though she sees me becoming thin day after day.

tgt_text.1753: The poet intending to celebrate Ptolemy Philadelphus, king of Egypt, sets out with the praise of his father, Ptolemy Lagus, to whom after his death a place among the gods had been ascribed ;
tgt_text.1754: and goes on to eulogize Berenice, the mother of Philadelphus, whom Venus was sup­ posed to have received into her temples to be her πάρεδρος, or assessor, He next proceeds to set forth the fortunes and virtues of Philadelphus himself, beginning with the happy omens which had attended his birth in the island of Cos, and portended his future opulence and power.
tgt_text.1755: Then follows an enumeration of the royal territories, and laudation of the royal wealth, augmented as it has been by the blessings of peace.
tgt_text.1756: The poet commends in glowing terms the munificence and discern­ ment of Philadelphus in conferring favours, as well as his filial piety shown so eminently.

tgt_text.1837: After the nuptials of Helen and Menelaus, the chief maidens of Sparta, ranging themselves before the bridal chamber, sing an Epithalamium, beginning with the jokes which would naturally be passed at the ex­ pense of the bridegroom.

tgt_text.1935: This Idyll contains a conversation of two fishermen by night.
tgt_text.1936: Our poet addressing one Diophantus with a few observations on the force of poverty in rousing men to active pursuits, describes the scene of this colloquy, which is laid in a scantily furnished sea-side but.

tgt_text.1941: His comrade bids him be of good cheer, telling him that his oath is clearly no more real than his dream was.

tgt_text.2001: This hymn to the Dioscuri is divided into two parts-the first (27—134) in praise of Pollux, the second of Castor.
tgt_text.2002: After a proem (1—26) sounding their common praises, a most renowned contest between Pollux and Amycus is described.

tgt_text.2009: When the Dioscuri had carried off the daughters of Leucippus, Idas and Lynceus, the sons of Aphareus, their betrothed lovers, overtake the ravishers at the tomb of Aphareus.

tgt_text.2180: But now I add farewell to your vestibule—I know what is coming.
tgt_text.2182: Both the rose is lovely, and time withers it.
tgt_text.2183: And the violet is beautiful in spring, yet quickly it grows old.
tgt_text.2186: the snow too is white, and it melts after it has become frozen.
tgt_text.2187: And the beauty of childhood is fair, yet it lives but a short space.
tgt_text.2188: That time shall come when even you will love ;
tgt_text.2189: when, scorched at your heart, you shall weep briny tears.
tgt_text.2190: Nay, do you, boy, even now for this last time, do a pleasant act, 14whensoever, having gone forth, you shall have beheld me suspended at your vestibule, pass me not by, wretch as I am, but stand and weep though briefly;
tgt_text.2191: and having shed the liba­ tion of a tear, loose me from the rope, and place about me gar­ ments from your limbs, and cover me, and for the last time 15 kiss me, and make the dead man a present of your lips.
tgt_text.2193: I cannot live, no, not if, having been recon­ ciled, you shall kiss me.
tgt_text.2194: And hollow me out a tomb, 16 which shall bury my love.
tgt_text.2195: And if you depart, 17 shout this over me thrice:
tgt_text.2197: Yes, and if you will, say this too:
tgt_text.2198: 'And for me a beautiful companion has perished.'
tgt_text.2199: And write this inscription, which I will engrave for 18you in verses:
tgt_text.2201: pass not by, but stop and say this, He had a cruel comrade.
tgt_text.2203: Thus having said, he took up a stone, and having planted it against a wall even to the middle of the door-posts, a dread­ ful stone, he proceeded 19to attach to them the slender rope, and began to throw the noose around his neck;
tgt_text.2204: and then he rolled the stepping-stone from under his foot, and hung, a corpse.
tgt_text.2205: But the other in his turn opened the doors, and beheld the dead man suspended from his own hall-door ;
tgt_text.2206: nor was he overcome in his spirit, nor did he weep 20for the slaughter of a young man :
tgt_text.2207: but yet more, he polluted for the dead man all the youthful garments, and proceeded to go to the contests of the wrestlers, and to seek, afar off, pleasant baths ;
tgt_text.2208: and he came to the god whom he had insulted, for Eros was standing on a stone basement above the waters.
tgt_text.2209: 21 And the statue leaped forth and slew the wretched youth, and the water became purpled, but the voice of the lad kept coming to the top.
tgt_text.2210: Rejoice, ye that love, for he who hated has been slain ;
tgt_text.2211: and ye, beloved youths, be affectionate, for the god knows how to punish.
tgt_text.2212: In this Idyll the first achievement of the boy Hercules is recounted, his victory, to wit, over the hostile dragons sent against him by Juno.
tgt_text.2213: Alcmena, terrified by this prodigy, (62,) sends for Teiresias, the seer, to explain it, and to point out means of appeasing the wrath of the gods.
tgt_text.2214: He comes, and unfolds the labours, the earthly and the hea­ venly glory which should attend the child, when grown to man's estate.
tgt_text.2215: He also orders the dragons to be burned, and the house to be purified.
tgt_text.2216: There follows an enumeration of the masters, whose train­ ing conduced to make Hercules a worthy hero.
tgt_text.2217: The end of the poem, which we may suppose to have gone deeply into the history of his training, has been lost..
tgt_text.2218: Valkenaer thinks that this Idyll, and the 25th, and the Megara of Moschus, are the three parts of one poem, the Heraclea of some nameless author.
tgt_text.2219: Reiske supposed Idylls 24th and 25th to be parts of the Heraclea of Pisander;
tgt_text.2220: but Kiessling points out that the non-preservation of the customs of the heroic age in these two Idylls disproves this theory.
tgt_text.2221: We may safely, with War­ ton, reckon it among the Idylls of Theocritus.ONCE upon a time Alcmena of 1 Midea, having washed both Hercules, now ten months old, and Iphiclus, younger by a night, and having filled them with milk, had laid them down in a 2brazen shield, which, a noble piece of armour, Amphi­ tryon had taken as spoil from fallen Pterelaus.
tgt_text.2222: And the woman, touching the head of her children, spake thus:
tgt_text.2223: 'Sleep, my babes, a sweet sleep, and one from which ye may awake;
tgt_text.2224: sleep, my lives, two brothers, secure children, happily may ye sleep, and happily arrive at morn.'
tgt_text.2225: Thus having said, she rocked the great shield, and sleep took possession of them.
tgt_text.2226: But what time 3 the Bear revolves at midnight toward the setting, opposite Orion himself, and he displays his broad shoulder, then in sooth Juno of many schemes set in motion two dreadful monsters, dragons bristling with azure coils, against the broad threshold, where the door-posts of the cham­ ber are hollow, having urged them by threats to devour the babe Hercules.
tgt_text.2227: These twain then having uncoiled themselves, were rolling their ravenous bellies along the ground;
tgt_text.2228: and 4from their eyes, as they went, evil fire was glancing, and they were spit- ting forth noxious venom.
tgt_text.2229: 5But when at length, licking their forked tongues, they had come nigh the boys, then, I wot, as Jove knoweth all things, the dear children of Alc­ mena awoke, and a light was raised all over the chamber.
tgt_text.2230: In truth, the one, namely Iphiclus, forthwith shouted out, when he perceived the evil monsters above the hollow shield, and saw their ruthless fangs ;
tgt_text.2231: and kicked away with his feet the fine coverlet, being eager to escape:
tgt_text.2232: but the other, Hercules, opposing them, held fast to them with his hands, and bound both in a firm grasp, having seized them by the throat, where baneful poisons, such as even the gods abhor, are wrought by murderous serpents.
tgt_text.2234: And they two, on the other hand, began to wind with their coils around the child, late-born, still a suckling, ever tearless under his nurse's care:
tgt_text.2235: but again they began to uncoil, since they were wearied in their spines, in trying to find a riddance from his constraining grasp.
tgt_text.2236: And Alcmena heard a cry, and awoke first.
tgt_text.2237: 'Rise, Amphitryon, for timid fear possesses me :
tgt_text.2238: rise, 7 nor put your sandals on your feet.
tgt_text.2239: Hear you not how greatly the younger of the children is crying?
tgt_text.2240: 8Or perceive you not that, some where in the early night, these walls also around are all plain to be seen, without the aid of clear dawn ?
tgt_text.2241: There is some strange thing, I know, in the house, there is, dear husband.
tgt_text.2244: and he, having complied with his wife's request, descended from his couch, and rushed in quest of his curiously-wrought sword, which was 9 always suspended for him upon a peg, above his cedar couch.
tgt_text.2245: In truth he was reaching after his new-spun belt, lifting in the other hand a large scabbard, a work wrought of the lotus;
tgt_text.2246: when, I wot, the spacious chamber was filled again with gloom.
tgt_text.2247: Then at length he shouted to the servants 10 snoring heavily in sleep :
tgt_text.2248: 'Bring fire with all speed, having snatched it from the hearth, my servants, and force back the strong bolts of the doors:
tgt_text.2249: rise, ye patient-hearted servants, 11 the master calls.'
tgt_text.2250: 12 The servants then speedily came forward with blazing lights, and the chamber was filled with the bustling of each.
tgt_text.2251: In good truth, I ween, when they saw the suckling Hercules tightly holding two monsters in his tender hands, they.
tgt_text.2252: shouted out, clapping their hands together:
tgt_text.2253: but he began to point out the serpents to his sire Amphitryon, and to leap aloft with joy in his boyishness, and laughingly he laid before his father's feet the dire monsters stupified with death.
tgt_text.2254: Alcmena indeed then took to her bosom, dry by reason of fear, Iphiclus in passion­ ate distress ;
tgt_text.2255: and Amphitryon placed the 13 other boy under his coverlet of wool, and again returned to his couch and was mindful of slumber.
tgt_text.2256: The cocks a third time now were pro­ claiming the last of dawn:
tgt_text.2257: then 14 Alcmena having summoned Teiresias the soothsayer, telling all things true, recounted to him the strange matter, and bade him answer how it was likely to end.
tgt_text.2258: 'And do not,' said sce, 15‘ if the gods intend any thing adverse, hide it from me through scruples:
tgt_text.2259: for that 'tis impossible for men to escape whatever the Fate 16 forces down the spindle, I teach thee, prophet son of Eueris, very wise though thou art!'
tgt_text.2262: ‘ Cheer up, lady, mother of noblest progeny, 17 of the blood of Perseus ;
tgt_text.2263: 18 for, by my dear light, long since gone from mine eyes, many Achaian women shall ply the soft yarn with the hand about the knee, 19at even-tide singing of Alcmena by name :
tgt_text.2264: 20 thou shalt be a glory to the women of Argos.
tgt_text.2265: This thy son, being such a hero, is about to ascend to the star-bearing heaven, 21 a hero with a broad chest, to whom both all monsters and all other men shall be inferior.
tgt_text.2266: To him it is fated, after he has accomplished twelve labours, to dwell in the halls of Jove:
tgt_text.2267: but all his mortal parts 22 the Trachinian pyre shall have.
tgt_text.2268: And he shall be called son-in- law of the very immortals, who set on these skulking monsters to destroy the babe.
tgt_text.2269: 23 In truth, that day shall come, when the sharp-toothed wolf, having seen the kid in his lair, shall not be willing to harm it.
tgt_text.2270: But, lady, let the fire be in readi­ ness, look you, under the ashes, and make ye ready dry logs of 24 aspalathus, or paliurus;
tgt_text.2272: or the brittle wild-pear wood shaken by the wind:
tgt_text.2273: and at midnight, when they wished to destroy thy child, burn these two dragons upon the wild cleft-wood.
tgt_text.2274: 25 Then at morn let one of the attendants, having gathered the ashes of the fire, carry and throw it thoroughly every whit across the river, upon the rugged rocks, over the boundary, and return home without turning back:
tgt_text.2275: but first of all 26 purify the house with clear sulphur, and next remember to sprinkle with a green branch 27 plenty of pure water, mixed, as is usual, with salt;
tgt_text.2276: and to sacrifice to supreme Jove a boar pig, that ye may ever be superior to your enemies.
tgt_text.2278: Teiresias spake, and withdrew with his ivory seat, though he was bent with the weight of many years.
tgt_text.2279: And Hercules was reared under his mother's care, like a 28 young plant in a garden, being called the son of Argive Amphitryon.
tgt_text.2280: Letters 29 aged Linus, son of Apollo, a sleepless guardian, a hero, taught the boy :
tgt_text.2281: and to bend the bow, and to be a good shot with arrows, 30 Eurytus, rich in broad lands from his forefathers.
tgt_text.2282: 31 Eumolpus, son of Philammon, made him a minstrel, and moulded both his hands upon a cithern of box- wood.
tgt_text.2283: And in how many ways men of Argos, throwing their adversaries from their legs with a cross-buttock, trip up each other in wrestling, and in how many ways boxers are formi­ dable in the cæstus, and what tricks adapted to their art men ready for every kind of contest have invented, by falling for­ ward to the earth, all these he learned under the teaching of 32 Harpalycus of Phanote, son of Mercury, whom not though beholding him afar off, could any one withstand, as he con­ tended in the games.
tgt_text.2284: Such a scowl rested on his awe-in­ spiring visage.
tgt_text.2285: Moreover, with feelings of love, Amphitryon himself was wont to teach his son to drive steeds in the chariot, and turning safely 33 round the post, to guard the box of the nave of the wheel, since full oft in equestrian Argos he had carried off prizes in contests of speed ;
tgt_text.2286: and his chariots on which he used to mount, 34 still unbroken, burst their reins by reason of age.
tgt_text.2287: But to aim at his man with outstretched spear, keeping his back under cover of his shield, and to bear up against sword-wounds, and to marshal a pha­ lanx, and in making his attack to measure again and again the ambuscades of the enemy, and to cheer on the cavalry, Castor the horseman taught him, having come an exile from Argos, what time 35 Tydeus was holding the whole inheritance and broad vineyard, having received equestrian Argos from Adrastus.
tgt_text.2288: Among the demigods was no other warrior like to Castor, before old age wore out his youthful vigour.
tgt_text.2289: Thus indeed his loving mother 36 had Hercules brought up.
tgt_text.2290: And a couch was made for the lad near his father, 37 a lion's skin, a couch very agreeable to himself:
tgt_text.2291: and 38 his dinner was roast-meat and a huge Dorian loaf in a bread basket;
tgt_text.2292: it would be safe to satisfy a digger and delver.
tgt_text.2293: But 39 at the close of day he was wont to take a little supper, uncooked;
tgt_text.2294: and he was clad in unembroidered garments 40 above the calf of the leg.
tgt_text.2295: In this fragmentary poem we find Hercules in the land of Elis, in the neighbourhood of the famous stables of Augeas.
tgt_text.2296: Having arrived thither, he is led to the king by an old rustic.
tgt_text.2297: The king has retired into the country to visit his herds.
tgt_text.2298: A description of a vast herd re­ turning from pasture is finely interwoven, (84—137,) and Hercules is exhibited repelling with ease the assault of the finest bull of the herd, a proof of valour which excites the admiration of the king and his son.
tgt_text.2299: This son of Augeas, as they travel by the same road, begs Her­ cules to recount to him, by what means he slew the Nemean lion.
tgt_text.2300: The hero, complying, narrates the whole exploit.
tgt_text.2301: Some have doubted whether Theocritus wrote this poem.
tgt_text.2302: It is variously assigned by such, to Pisander, a contemporary of Tyrtæus, to some unknown poet earlier than the date of Theocritus, and to some Alexandrine Rhapso­ dist.
tgt_text.2303: Hermann deems it not unworthy of Theocritus.
tgt_text.2304: Old editions have prefixed to this Idyll a poor attempt of some nameless gram­ marian to furnish a beginning.
tgt_text.2305: And to him spake the old man, a husbandman 1in charge of the tillage, having ceased from the work which lay on his hands :
tgt_text.2307: Stranger, I will readily tell over to you all that you ask, since I stand in awe of the dread vengeance of 2 Hermes by the wayside.
tgt_text.2308: For they say, that, most of all the gods of heaven, he is incensed, if so be that any one spurn a traveller very anxious to know the way.
tgt_text.2309: The fleecy flocks indeed of king Augeas 3feed not all on one pasture, or one spot;
tgt_text.2310: but some, I ween, pasture round about on the banks of 4 Elisus, others beside the sacred stream of divine 5 Alpheus, others again hard by 6Buprasium teeming with grapes, and others also here.
tgt_text.2311: Now separately, for each of these, folds have been built.
tgt_text.2312: But for all the herds, overflowing though they are, still there are here pastures ever rich, along the wide standing- waters of 7 Menius ;
tgt_text.2313: 8 for dewy meads and water-pastures luxuriate in fragant herbage in abundance, which in sooth increases the strength of horned heifers.
tgt_text.2314: And here, to your right hand, appears their stall, all of it quite on the other side of the flowing river, in that quarter where the planes grow all the year long, and the green- wild olive, a sacred holy-grove of 9 pastoral Apollo, a most perfect god, stranger.
tgt_text.2315: And right forwards are built very spacious dwellings for us husbandmen, who zealously guard for the king his great and untold wealth, sometimes casting 10the seed into thrice-plough­ ed fallows, and in like manner into four times ploughed.
tgt_text.2316: Now his boundaries the diggers and delvers know, who, hard- workingfellows, come to the wine vats, when the ripe summer season shall have arrived.
tgt_text.2317: For in truth all this is the plain of prudent Augeas, and these his wheat-bearing " acres and wooded orchards, even to the extreme points of the moun­ tain ridge having-many-springs, which we ply with our labour all day long, as is the law for servants, whose life is a-field.
tgt_text.2318: But tell you also me, [which likewise will be better for yourself,] 12 being in need of what have you come here ?
tgt_text.2319: Either, I suppose, you seek Augeas, or one of his servants, whom he has.
tgt_text.2320: Now I, look you, can fully tell you every par­ ticular, as I know them accurately ;
tgt_text.2321: for I think that you at any rate come not of evil people, nor are yourself like unto evil men, such a noble figure is conspicuous about you :
tgt_text.2322: surely, methinks, of such a stamp are the sons of immortals among mortal men.'
tgt_text.2323: And him the valorous son of Jove addressed in answer:
tgt_text.2324: ‘Yes, old man, I would wish to see Augeas, ruler of the Epeans, for it was even a want of this which brought me here.
tgt_text.2325: But if now he is abiding in the city among his citizens, engaged in caring for his people, and is deciding questions of law, prythee, aged sir, bid you one of the servants to be my guide, whosoever is the most honour­ able 13 manager over these lands, to whom I might say some­ what, and from whom I might learn somewhat, when he speaks.
tgt_text.2326: For God, in sooth, hath made one man in need of one, and / another of another.
tgt_text.2327: 'And him the old man, trusty husbandman as he was, an­ swered yet again :
tgt_text.2329: By the advice, stranger, of some one of the gods you come hither.
tgt_text.2330: Since to you every business, which you wish, quickly finds its accomplishment.
tgt_text.2331: For hither bath come but 14 yesterday from town Augeas, dear son of the Sun, with his child, the strong and noble Phyleus, to visit after many days the property, which he has in countless extent in the country.
tgt_text.2332: Thus, I suppose, even to princes their house seems to be safer, to their mind, if they manage it themselves.
tgt_text.2333: But let us go to him by all means ;
tgt_text.2334: and I will be your guide to my stall, where we shall find the king.
tgt_text.2335: 'Thus having spoken, he began to lead the way ;
tgt_text.2336: but 15 in mind he at least was pondering much, as he saw the lion's skin, and the club, which filled his hand, whence the stranger could be :
tgt_text.2337: and he was eager to question him.
tgt_text.2338: But again through fear he was keeping within his lips his speech as it rose, lest he should address to him, in his haste, any inoppor­ tune word :
tgt_text.2339: for 'tis hard to know another man's mind.
tgt_text.2340: And as they approached, 16the dogs quickly noticed them from afar off, in both ways, by their scent of flesh, and by the sound of feet.
tgt_text.2341: And barking furiously they rushed from different sides on Hercules, son of Amphitryon :
tgt_text.2342: but about the old man, barking without need or cause, they kept fawning on the other side.
tgt_text.2343: These indeed he for his part proceeded to frighten into retreating, by stones, merely lifting them from the ground;
tgt_text.2344: and sharply with his voice did he threaten every one of them and check their barking, though he rejoiced in his heart that they protected his stall, yes, when he was absent;
tgt_text.2345: then spake he such words as these :
tgt_text.2347: what an animal this is, that the gods our rulers have made to be with men :
tgt_text.2349: if it had but a mind, so far intelligent, within, as to know with whom 'twere right to be angry, and with whom not, then no other of brutes had vied with it for the meed of honour.
tgt_text.2350: But, as it is, 'tis a very wrathful kind of beast, and 17 savage to no purpose.
tgt_text.2353: and speedily they came in their progress to the stall.
tgt_text.2354: The 18 Sun indeed at that time had turned his steeds towards the west, bringing on eventide:
tgt_text.2355: and the fat sheep arrived, coming up from pasture to their 19 folds and pens.
tgt_text.2356: Next full myriads of heifers were seen, one after another, com­ ing, like rainy clouds, as many as in the heaven are being driven forward, either by force of the south wind, or of Thracian Boreas:
tgt_text.2357: of which there is no numbering, as they move in air, no, nor cessation ;
tgt_text.2358: for so many does the violence of the wind roll after the first, and the rest too rise and swell upon others again :
tgt_text.2359: so many herds of heifers, Isay, were coming up ever and anon behind.
tgt_text.2360: Then in sooth all the plain was filled, and all the ways, with the cattle coming in, while the fertile fields were full of lowings, and the stalls easily crowded with trailing-footed oxen ;
tgt_text.2361: the sheep too were fold­ ing themselves in the pens.
tgt_text.2362: 20 Here, indeed, no man, though they were numberless, stood inactive by the oxen, in lack of work :
tgt_text.2363: but one was fitting with well-cut thongs wooden logs about the cows' feet, for the purpose of standing close beside to milk them.
tgt_text.2364: Another, again, was putting the dear calves to their own mothers, all eager as they were to drink of the pleasant milk :
tgt_text.2366: another was 21 thickening a rich cheese ;
tgt_text.2367: another was driving in the bulls, apart from the cows.
tgt_text.2368: And Augeas was going over all the ox- stalls, and noting what fruits of his possessions his herdsmen were making for him.
tgt_text.2369: And with him his son as well as mighty and wise Hercules were following, as the king went round his large property.
tgt_text.2370: Hereupon the son of Amphitryon, though hav­ ing in his bosom a spirit unbroken 22 and sternly fixed for ever, yet was vastly astonished on seeing the countless tribe of oxen, I ween.
tgt_text.2371: For no one would say, or 23 have supposed, that the stock of one man, no, nor of ten others, ay, such as were rich in flocks beyond all other men, was so great.
tgt_text.2372: Since Phoebus had presented to his son this special gift, to be rich in cattle above all men;
tgt_text.2373: yes, and he kept altogether prospering for him all his beasts to the uttermost;
tgt_text.2374: 24 for no disease, of those which destroy the labours of herdsmen, assailed his herds.
tgt_text.2375: But ever more in number, ever finer sprang up horned heifers duly from year to year:
tgt_text.2376: for of a truth all were 25mothers of live offspring, far beyond others, and all of fe­ male offspring.
tgt_text.2377: And together with these, three hundred bulls were ranged in rows, white-legged and crumple-horned ;
tgt_text.2378: nay, there were other two hundred red;
tgt_text.2379: and all such as were even already full-grown.
tgt_text.2380: And other twelve again beside these were feeding, 26 sacred to the Sun, and in colour they were like swans, so white were they, and they were conspicu­ ous among all the trailing-footed oxen, which also were feeding on the verdant herbage apart from the herd in the pasture ;
tgt_text.2381: so exceedingly were they exulting over themselves.
tgt_text.2382: And whensoever swift wild beasts chanced to sally forth from the bushy thicket into the plain, for the sake of heifers afield, these were they, I wot, that would rush first to the con­ flict, guided by their scent of the skin ;
tgt_text.2383: and bellow fearfully, 27looking slaughter in their visages.
tgt_text.2384: And chief of them in­ deed both in strength, and in his natural force and high courage, was huge Phaethon :
tgt_text.2385: whom in sooth herdsmen were all 28 wont to liken to a star, because as he moved he shone out greatly among other oxen, and was very conspicuous.
tgt_text.2386: Now he in fact, when he beheld the dry hide of a fierce-eyed lion, upon this rushed against wary Hercules himself, so as to bring against his sides his head and sturdy forehead.
tgt_text.2387: But, as he approached, 29the hero quickly seized his left horn with his broad hand, bent his neck, so hard though it was, down to the earth beneath ;
tgt_text.2388: and then thrust him back again, having pressed heavily with his shoulder ;
tgt_text.2389: so the bull, having the tendons of the muscles strained, stood right up on his haunches.
tgt_text.2390: Then marvelled both the king himself, and Phyleus, his war­ like son, and the herdsmen over 31 crumple-horned kine, as they beheld the immense strength of the son of Amphitryon.
tgt_text.2391: Then they two, Phyleus and strong Hercules, began to pro­ ceed to the city, having left there behind them the fruitful fields.
tgt_text.2392: But as soon as they had set 32 foot on the highway, having got over 33 with active feet a narrow path which in sooth extended through the vineyard from the ox-stalls, not being in any way very distinguishable amid green foliage, here then, I say, the dear son of Augeas addressed the offspring of highest Jove, as he came on behind him, having slightly bent his head over his right shoulder :
tgt_text.2393: 34 ‘Stranger, I am just now pondering in my mind, that I have certainly heard long ago some famous story about thee.
tgt_text.2394: For there came hither on his way from Argos, one, 35 quite a young man, an Achæan from 36 Helice by the sea-shore, who in truth, look you, was also discoursing among many of the Epeans, that one of the Argives in his presence had destroyed a wild beast, a savage lion, a monster of evil to rustics, having a hollow den 37 in the grove of Nemean Jupiter.
tgt_text.2395: I know not accurately, whether he was from 38 sacred Argos, on the spot, or an inhabitant of the city of Tiryns, or Mycenæ.
tgt_text.2396: Thus he at least used to say :
tgt_text.2397: but by birth he reported that the hero was (that is, if I recollect rightly) 39 of the lineage of Perseus.
tgt_text.2398: I deem that none other of the 40 Ægialæans, but you, has had the courage to do this deed, and the wild beast's hide, which envelopes your sides, very clearly bespeaks the work of your hands.
tgt_text.2399: Come now, tell me first, (that I may know in my mind, O hero, whether I guess rightly or not,) if even you are that hero, 41 of whom the Achæan from Helice told us, his hearers, and I judge of you rightly.
tgt_text.2400: And tell me how you yourself slew this dreadful wild beast, and how it came into the land of well-watered Nemea.
tgt_text.2401: For such a monster you could not find, though you desired to see it, in 42 Apis;
tgt_text.2402: since it surely rears none such, but only bears, and wild boars, 43 and the destructive seed of wolves.
tgt_text.2403: Whereat they used to wonder then, as they heard the story, and some too even thought that the traveller was telling a falsehood, giving freely of a false tongue to please present company.
tgt_text.2404: 'Thus having spoken, Phyleus 44 made way from the middle of the road, that it might suffice for them to walk together upon, and also, I ween, that he might more easily hear Her­ cules speak, who, having accompanied him, addressed him in such a speech as follows.'

tgt_text.2602: This sweet ditty was written to commend an ivory distaff, which the poet, about to sail to Miletus, intended as a present for Theugenis, the wife of Nicias the physician.

tgt_text.2651: When Venus, on the death of Adonis, had bidden a boar, the author of the crime, be brought before her, the animal tries to excuse his sin, by pleading, that he had been smitten by love of the beauteous youth, and had therefore longed to kiss his limbs.

tgt_text.3208: Ill-fated am I, who, since I have come to the bed of a faultless hero, whom I did honour indeed like my own eyes, ay, even now both worship and reverence him in my heart.
tgt_text.3209: But than him has no other of living beings been more ill-starred, or tasted so many cares in his own thoughts ;
tgt_text.3210: wretched man, who with the 2bow and arrows, which Apollo himself had provided for him, dire weapons either of one of the Fates, or of Erinnys, 3 slew his own children, and robbed them of their dear life, as he raged about his house, and it was full of slaughter.
tgt_text.3211: Them indeed I, wretched woman, beheld with mine own eyes, stricken by their father;
tgt_text.3212: and this bath befallen no other even in a dream:

tgt_text.3216: And even as a bird laments over her nestlings as they perish, which while still in infancy a fierce snake devours amid the thick bushes, while she, kind mother, hovers over them shrieking very shrilly, yet is not able, I ween, to succour her children ;
tgt_text.3217: for in truth, she herself hath a great dread of coming nigher to the ruthless monster;
tgt_text.3218: so I, most wretched mother, wailing for mine own offspring, with frantic feet kept running to and fro through my house fre­ quently.

tgt_text.3250: For be Proserpine and richly-robed Demeter witnesses, (by whom with great hurt to himself would any of our foes Swear wilfully a false oath,) that in mine heart I love thee not a whit less, than if thou hadst come from out my womb, and wert to me in mine house a 14late-born daughter:

tgt_text.3252: Wherefore say not ever,15 my young shoot, that I care not for thee, not even if I wail more con­ stantly than fair-haired Niobe:
tgt_text.3253: for 'tis no cause of blame for a mother to weep over an afflicted son:
tgt_text.3254: since for ten months did I labour, before even I first beheld him, whilst I had him in my womb, and he brought me near to 16 Hell's gate-keeper Pluto;
tgt_text.3255: so severe throes did I endure when about to travail hard with him.
tgt_text.3256: But now my son is gone to accomplish a fresh toil on a foreign land, nor know I, ill-starred woman, whether I shall welcome him again having returned hither, or not.
tgt_text.3257: And besides also a fearful dream has scared me during sweet sleep;
tgt_text.3258: and I fear exceedingly, having seen a hurtful vision, lest it betide something untoward to my chil­ dren.
tgt_text.3259: For my son, stout Hercules, seemed to me to hold in both his hands a well-made spade, with which he was delving, as one that had taken the work for hire, a dyke at the outskirt of some flourishing field, stripped, without cloak, and well­ girdled tunic:
tgt_text.3260: but when he had arrived at the end of all the work, labouring at the strong fence of a levelled plot for vines, in truth, he was about, having placed his 17shovel upon the projecting raised bank, to put on the garments, in which he had been clad before;
tgt_text.3261: when, on a sudden, above the deep trench there blazed up a fierce fire, and a vast flame was gathering round him:
tgt_text.3262: but he kept ever drawing back with swift feet, desiring to escape the destructive weapon of He­ phaestus ;
tgt_text.3263: and continually in front of his person he was brand­ ishing, as a 18 shield, his spade:
